text: <@U61NXB13P> A busy week continues. Today I am in Berlin for the start of a two day conference. There will be lots of presentations about the European energy industry, but it's mainly an opportunity to network, meeting old clients and colleagues as well as hopefully meeting potential future clients.
What are the best and worst elements you find through sitting down in presentations all day? Don't you ever get bored through them? Are they all the same? With the same structure?

Good question. Some of the presentations are very interesting - if they look at a topic from a different perspective there can be some interesting things to learn. But for the most part there is nothing new, and yes, it can get pretty boring. But the coffee breaks and lunch are a fun chance to catch up with people, so it's worth it.

Also, I mentioned books that combine law and history in an interesting way. The one I had in mind is "The Nuremberg Trial" by the Tusas - it is a really interesting look at how complicated the legal questions around the trial were, how it was organised, and recounts the trial itself in a very interesting way. Makes what was actually a very tedious process very interesting.
